_comment: This data is an early work-in-progress and contains errors. Produced by @michaelh at Discuss and Discover SuttaCentral forum - please get in touch! Finished code forthcoming.

The four right efforts [sn49.1-12:4.4]: Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
How a mendicant who develops the four ri: Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.
Generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
The two sixes (a repetitive sentence str: Six on slanting to the east
Six on slanting to the ocean
